asynchronous-patterns--slide.title: Asynchronous Patterns
asynchronous-patterns--slide.text:
At it's core, JavaScript is a synchronous, blocking, single-threaded language. This means that only one thing can happen at a time.

We use tools, such as ...
  • Callbacks
  • Pomises
  • Observable
  • Signals
... to make it behave asynchronously.
asynchronous-patterns--slide.notes:
What we want to do throughout this talk is look at how these patterns are created and used.

Based on this deeper understanding, we can think more logically about the patterns we are creating and using.

I equate this to the difference between a driver, a driver that can change the oil, and a mechanic. Each has an understanding of how a car works, but the mechanic has a depth of understanding that allows him to do much more with a vehicle.

callbacks--slide.title: Callback Pattern
callbacks--slide.text:
The Callback Pattern is the key to asynchronous execution,

... and our understanding of how it's handled moving forward.
callbacks--slide.notes: Using this mechanism we can build JavaScript applications that make use of external APIs that might be unreliable, or take a comparatively long time to return results, without freezing the application while it's waiting for an API.

promise--slide.title: Promise Pattern
promise--slide.text:
The Promise Pattern allows for asynchronous execution of JavaScript code which is aided by external APIs,

... but are often times, confused to be asynchronous themselves.
promise--slide.notes: Using this mechanism we can build JavaScript applications that make use of external APIs that might be unreliable, or take a comparatively long time to return results, without freezing the application while it's waiting for an API.

promise--code.title: Promise Exercise
promise--code.notes:
In the Simple Promise Example, we can handle simple asynchronous activity (setTimeout).

In the Improved Promise Example, we can handle asynchronous activity, resolving, and rejecting.

In the Chained Promise Example, we've added logic to return a promise on the use of then, and identified if we've been passed a ChainedPromise or a resolution of some sort.

pubsub--slide.title: PubSub Pattern
pubsub--slide.text:
The Publish/Subscribe Pattern is a crutial pattern to leverage the understanding of building scalable, maintainable, and responsive applications.

It not only promotes clean code but also enables efficient communication between components.
pubsub--slide.notes: It helps developers understand the internal functioning of many libraries and frameworks, as the Pub-Sub pattern is often used as a core concept in various programming environments.
